fields.en-Tagline: Mapping household air quality
fields.Research Blurb: While outdoor air chemistry is a much-studied discipline, the science of indoor air chemistry has been less explored — until recently. Most U.S. residents spend 90% of their time indoors, and the combination of chemicals and products used for everyday household activities like cooking and cleaning can lead to unexpected and potentially harmful airborne chemical compounds. CSU atmospheric chemist Delphine Farmer and her CU collaborator Marina Vance won a Sloan Foundation grant to map the airborne chemistry of a typical home — a first-of-its-kind project dubbed HOMEChem — which will serve as a baseline study of what a person at home, doing typical home activities, can expect to breathe.
fields.Spatial Angle: Hmmm
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Most U.S. residents spend 90% of their time indoors, and the combination of chemicals and products used for everyday household activities like cooking and cleaning can lead to unexpected and potentially harmful airborne chemical compounds.
fields.sp-Tagline: Mapping household air quality
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Most U.S. residents spend 90% of their time indoors, and the combination of chemicals and products used for everyday household activities like cooking and cleaning can lead to unexpected and potentially harmful airborne chemical compounds.

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.en-Tagline: Saving lives from the world's most extreme weather
fields.Research Blurb: V. "Chandra" Chandrasekaran, professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at CSU, is one of the world's leading experts in geoscience and remote sensing — a field that uses data from satellites to advance understanding of the land, oceans, atmosphere, and space. His work with meteorological radar systems has led to technologies that protect lives and improve weather forecasting all over the world — including Finland, where he was knighted by the government for his international work.
fields.Spatial Angle: Locations with severe hurricanes and tornados: If this exists, let's not recreate it.
fields.sp-Tagline: Saving lives from the world's most extreme weather

fields.en-Tagline: Community-based rangeland management
fields.Research Blurb: What we call things matters, and when it comes to streams and small waterways, it can matter a lot. Under the EPA’s recent Navigable Waters Protection Rule, streams classified as “ephemeral streams” — those which only flow briefly after rain or snowmelt — are not protected under the Clean Water Act. With fewer protections, more pollutants can be washed downstream — but some streams classified as ephemeral may actually be intermittent or seasonal, which would qualify them for protection. That’s where CSU professor Dr. Stephanie Kampf comes in. Dr. Kampf has been working for four years to map and define small headwater streams. Kampf and her team recently enlisted the help of the public through the Stream Tracker Project, an app that allows users to collect and submit their own data on nearby waterways.
fields.Spatial Angle: Ask researcher for maps of watersheds that they have created (maps mentioned in blurb)
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Under the EPA’s recent Navigable Waters Protection Rule, streams classified as “ephemeral streams” — those which only flow briefly after rain or snowmelt — are not protected under the Clean Water Act.
fields.sp-Tagline: Community-based rangeland management
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Under the EPA’s recent Navigable Waters Protection Rule, streams classified as “ephemeral streams” — those which only flow briefly after rain or snowmelt — are not protected under the Clean Water Act.

fields.Research Focus: Plant Pathogens - China and the Philippines
fields.en-Tagline: Combating world hunger one grain of rice at a time
fields.Research Blurb: Dr. Jan Leach, associate dean for research and professor of Bioagricultural Sciences and Pest Management in the College of Agricultural Sciences at CSU, combats world hunger one grain of rice at a time. Defending one of the world's most important food crops from the ravages of pests and climate change, driven by a strong sense of purpose in her work, Leach partners closely with rice growers and scientific collaborators in the Philippines and worldwide. She believes collaboration is key to protecting the food that sustains most of the developing world.
fields.sp-Tagline: Combating world hunger one grain of rice at a time

fields.en-Tagline: How one bite can alter the world
fields.Research Blurb: After a mosquito takes a bloodmeal from its host, it can be thought of as a small, flying syringe. If we can trap these insects and study the contents of their bloodmeals, we can understand not only which mammal the mosquito took a bloodmeal from but also which infectious diseases they may be carrying. Working in Guatemala, CSU professor Greg Ebel's lab is exploiting these feeding patterns to better characterize which viruses, bacteria, and parasites are circulating in humans and animals.
fields.Spatial Angle: Population density heat map of mosquitos around the world; what is the interactive component here? Can we look at a feeding pattern of a single mosquito? Or a few examples?
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: According to the World Health Organization, vector-borne diseases account for more than 700,000 deaths annually.
fields.sp-Tagline: How one bite can alter the world
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: According to the World Health Organization, vector-borne diseases account for more than 700,000 deaths annually.

fields.en-Tagline: Redefining what it means to "recycle" plastics
fields.Research Blurb: Chemistry brought us plastics, and now CSU professor Eugene Chen is using chemistry to save us from these synthetic materials and their unintended environmental impacts. Roughly 56 million tons of plastic trash are overflowing the world's landfills and bobbing in our oceans. By 2050, this means there will be more plastic (by weight) in the oceans than fish. Chen and his research team are creating fully recyclable polymers that can compete with conventional petroleum plastics.
fields.Spatial Angle: Global map of plastic waste per country... how do we make this interactive?
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: The world fell in love with plastics because they are cheap, convenient, lightweight, and long-lasting.
fields.sp-Tagline: Redefining what it means to "recycle" plastics
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: The world fell in love with plastics because they are cheap, convenient, lightweight, and long-lasting.

fields.en-Tagline: Why the world needs all kinds of minds
fields.Research Blurb: Individuals on the autism spectrum have different ways of thinking. Some are photorealistic visual thinkers, others are pattern thinkers who view things spatially, and still others think verbally. And CSU Professor Dr. Temple Grandin says the world needs all these different kinds of minds engaged in solving problems.
fields.sp-Tagline: Why the world needs all kinds of minds

fields.en-Tagline: The impacts of climate change and infectious disease on polar bears
fields.Research Blurb: Many species of wildlife have been adversely impacted, or even have gone extinct, due to climate change. Polar bears, however, have become the poster species, as the effects of climate change are the most pronounced in the Arctic due to rapidly melting sea ice. Colleen Duncan, a veterinary pathologist at CSU, studies infectious disease and population dynamics in wildlife, and works with wildlife researchers at the U.S. Geological Survey and the U.S. Department of Agriculture to collect biological samples and health data from polar bears in northernmost Alaska.
fields.Spatial Angle: Alaska study area; this could be an interactive map about health... let's push on how to make this a bit more dynamic and less locational.
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Climate change is melting sea ice at a hastening pace, pushing polar bears from their historic hunting grounds to dry land.
fields.sp-Tagline: The impacts of climate change and infectious disease on polar bears
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Climate change is melting sea ice at a hastening pace, pushing polar bears from their historic hunting grounds to dry land.

fields.en-Tagline: Studying energy production and environmental justice
fields.Research Blurb: The world’s population is expected to exceed 9 billion by 2050. With this growth will come heightened demand for clean water, healthy food, manufactured goods, and abundant energy — all requiring accelerated natural resource development and extraction. Stephanie Malin, environmental sociology professor and founding member of the Center for Environmental Justice at CSU, researches the impacts and outcomes of energy production and globalization on the health and sustainability of Earth’s finite ecosystems, resources, and communities. In her book, The Price of Nuclear Power: Uranium Communities and Environmental Justice, Malin asks whether nuclear power provides a socially sustainable solution in the age of climate change mitigation, exploring the intersection of legacy uranium mining and current efforts to renew uranium production at sites such as the Piñon Ridge Uranium Mill in western Colorado.
fields.Spatial Angle: Map of Oil and Gas infastrucutre in Colorado that brings together population growth and water somehow.
fields.sp-Tagline: Studying energy production and environmental justice
fields.sp-StoryTitle: El precio de la energía nuclear

fields.en-Tagline: Strategic marketing against human trafficking
fields.Research Blurb: There are currently more than 40 million victims of slavery around the world, with most of them being women and girls. This illegal industry generates approximately $150 billion every year. Dr. Lumina Albert, associate professor of management in the College of Business at CSU, applies her background in management and marketing to the fight against human trafficking in the U.S. and abroad. As a board member for Rescue:Freedom International and consultant for other organizations, Albert provides key input on issues ranging from strategic public relations to organizing social marketing campaigns.
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: There are more than 40 million victims of slavery around the world and most of them are women and girls.
fields.sp-Tagline: Strategic marketing against human trafficking
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: There are more than 40 million victims of slavery around the world and most of them are women and girls.

fields.en-Tagline: Human-Environmental Adaptability, Vulnerability, and Interaction
fields.Research Blurb: For pastoral people in East Africa, daily life revolves around the herd of animals that sustain them — and the land they travel to make sure the animals have room to graze and grow. As the climate changes, their traditional lifestyles are also changing, from subsistence to greater reliance on local villages for food, health care, and other services. CSU Anthropologist Kathleen Galvin has spent 30 years learning from the people who populate East African savannas. Listening to the Maasai share knowledge of climate change and the challenges it creates in their daily lives, Galvin also brings them together in a conversation with scientists and civil leaders to better understand the real human impacts of climate change on this vulnerable population.
fields.Spatial Angle: Kenya on a map of Africa
fields.sp-Tagline: Human-Environmental Adaptability, Vulnerability, and Interaction

fields.en-Tagline: Blocking transmission of malaria in Burkina Faso
fields.Research Blurb: Malaria, a preventable and potentially fatal disease transmitted by mosquitos, kills 445,000 people, mostly children, each year. In Burkina Faso, nearly every single person has malaria parasites in his or her system during the rainy season, and children can get the disease repeatedly before they develop immunity. Dr. Brian Foy, a professor in the Department of Microbiology, Immunology and Pathology at CSU, found that the use of Ivermectin, typically used to treat parasitic worms, led to a significant reduction in cases of malaria among children under the age of five. While Ivermectin has been known to kill blood feeding insects like mosquitos, Dr. Foy thinks it may also have an effect on the malaria parasite inside the body. If he's right, the findings could have implications for communities and inviduals across West Africa.
fields.sp-Tagline: Blocking transmission of malaria in Burkina Faso

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
Unit/Program: Energy Institute; Engines & Energy Conversion Laboratory
fields.en-Tagline: Harnessing clean and affordable energy in Rwanda
fields.Research Blurb: Electric power is scarce in Rwanda, where 1-in-4 people has an electric hookup, a hookup rate that drops to 1-in-10 in rural areas. CSU professor Bryan Willson’s work harnessing the University’s energy expertise to bring clean, affordable energy to Rwanda is just one example of Willson’s 25 years of work in more than 40 countries. The teams in Willson’s research lab, the Engines and Energy Conversion Lab are innovators in world needs like energy production and engine technology, advanced electrical grids, and biofuels. In Rwanda, AC/DC microgrids are powering people’s daily lives and boosting the entire country’s economic wellbeing.
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Electric power is scarce in Rwanda, where 1-in-4 people have an electric hookup, a hookup rate that drops to 1-in-10 in rural areas.
fields.sp-Tagline: Harnessing clean and affordable energy in Rwanda
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Electric power is scarce in Rwanda, where 1-in-4 people have an electric hookup, a hookup rate that drops to 1-in-10 in rural areas.

fields.Research Focus: Climate change and pastorial livelihoods - Mongolia
fields.en-Tagline: Community-based rangeland management
fields.Research Blurb: Rangelands make up three-quarters of Mongolia and are vitally important to the Mongolian people, and important to wildlife populations globally. Since 2008, CSU professor Maria Fernández-Giménez has led the Mongolian Rangelands and Resilience Project, tracking the impacts of ecological and climate change on Mongolia’s traditional herding families and strengthening connections between natural resource science and the country’s policymakers. Fernández-Giménez was awarded the Order of the Polar Star in 2016 — the highest civilian honor Mongolia bestows on foreign nationals.
fields.Spatial Angle: Let's brainstorm this map. It would be cool to do something that plays with policy and rangeland use...
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Rangelands make up three-quarters of Mongolia and are vitally important to the Mongolian people, and important to wildlife populations globally.
fields.sp-Tagline: Community-based rangeland management
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Rangelands make up three-quarters of Mongolia and are vitally important to the Mongolian people, and important to wildlife populations globally.

fields.Research Focus: Enviro Justice, Uranium Mining - Navajo Nation
fields.en-Tagline: Understanding the impacts of uranium toxicity on Navajo Nation
fields.Research Blurb: In 1979, toxic and radioactive material from the Church Rock uranium mill in Northwest New Mexico spilled into the Puerco River and made its way onto the Navajo Nation, whose people were not alerted of the spill’s toxic dangers until days later. It was not until 2008, however, that Congress authorized a five-year cleanup plan for the affected area. Dr. Gilbert John, a CSU microbiologist and member of the Navajo Nation, works to study and better understand the health issues and psychological impacts of the uranium disaster on the Navajo people, who used the river's water for drinking, irrigation, and livestock. John also actively empowers young Native students to pursue careers in STEM disciplines.
fields.Spatial Angle:
Navajo Nation; layering toxic and radioactive material zones with known spills + tribal nations around the U.S.?

Perhaps work from a map like this: https://www.epa.gov/navajo-nation-uranium-cleanup
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Uranium mining on Navajo lands took began in the 1940s and to this day, the Navajo people are still exposed to levels of radioactive materials which can contribute to adverse health effects.
fields.sp-Tagline: Understanding the impacts of uranium toxicity on Navajo Nation
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Uranium mining on Navajo lands took began in the 1940s and to this day, the Navajo people are still exposed to levels of radioactive materials which can contribute to adverse health effects.

fields.en-Tagline: Supporting elephant resiliency and survival
fields.Research Blurb: An estimated 100,000 elephants were killed in Africa for the ivory in their tusks and teeth from 2010 to 2012 alone. Elephants are among the slowest-producing mammals in the world; and it could take almost a century for forest elephants to recover from these intense levels of poaching. Despite this pressure, the structure of their social networks has remained remarkably stable. World-renowned elephant expert and CSU associate professor George Wittemeyer has spent his career of more than 20 years tracking elephants. He has tracked more than 1,000 individuals and 70 families to date — studying not only the effects of poaching on elephant populations and their social bonds, but the effects of habitat destruction from railroad, highway, and oil pipeline construction, and the resiliency of elephant communities.
fields.Spatial Angle: Map of Samburu, Kenya: 0.567 N 37.518 E (place of research): incorporate elephant tracking in some way to make this map interactive
fields.sp-Tagline: Supporting elephant resiliency and survival

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Research Focus: chemical pathways for diseases -- research in Thailand on malaria, HIV, etc.
fields.en-Tagline: Calculating chemical pathways for diseases
fields.Research Blurb: It is not enough to develop a drug to combat disease; scientists must also discover the proper dose. While some of this testing is done on animals, Dr. Brad Reisfeld, professor in the CSU Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, saw a different way — a mathematical approach, modeling biological systems and chemical pathways to better understand the effects of drugs on humans and animals. Dr. Reisfeld's research has been used to optimize dosing for pulmonary tuberculosis, as well as several diseases important in Thailand such as malaria, HIV, and Steven-Johnson Syndrome.
fields.sp-Tagline: Calculating chemical pathways for diseases

fields.en-Tagline: Economically sustainable futures for rural villages
fields.Research Blurb: Approximately 16% of the world’s population (1.2 billion people) lives without electricity, imposing a major barrier to participating in today’s economy. Dale Manning and the Smart Village Microgrid Laboratory seek to test and install energy microgrids in rural Rwandan communities to provide local and sustainable sources of electricity for years to come. To achieve village-level electrification, the CSU Energy Institute is working with the University of Rwanda to build mirrored microgrid labs at both locations to facilitate continued collaboration between the two institutions.
fields.Spatial Angle: World at night map with Rwandan boundary overlayed...or how can we play with light in the map? How can we look at access to power around the world, and in Rwanda specifically, by "lighting up the map"?
fields.sp-Tagline: Economically sustainable futures for rural villages

fields.Research Focus: LiDAR/Archaeology - Mexico, Central and South America
fields.en-Tagline: Archaeology as "future building" from the past
fields.Research Blurb: In Honduras, a previously hidden ancient city came to light when archaeologist and CSU professor Chris Fisher used LiDAR technology to look under the dense tree canopy and undergrowth of the jungle. Fisher’s groundbreaking, or really ground-viewing, use of LiDAR has changed the face of modern archaeology, speeding discovery by radically shortening the time it takes to “uncover” previously undiscovered sites. Ultimately, Fisher’s research expeditions in the jungles of Honduras and Mexico aim to help us better understand the causes and consequences of urbanism and environmental change.
fields.Spatial Angle: Amanda: I am open to where we take this. Ideas include locations where this LiDAR technology has been used to uncover ancient cities or finding existing map assets that could be dynamic and engaging. Slide 3.
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: LiDAR – short for light detection and ranging – is a scanning technology similar to radar, that can be used to reveal an inverted topographical map.
fields.sp-Tagline: Archaeology as "future building" from the past
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: LiDAR – short for light detection and ranging – is a scanning technology similar to radar, that can be used to reveal an inverted topographical map.

fields.en-Tagline: How naming can prevents extinction
fields.Research Blurb: Most people are familiar with the plight of polar bears affected by climate change, or rhinos affected by poaching, but few are likely familiar with the huemul — the rarest species of deer in the Americas, described as a mix of a kangaroo and a mountain goat in a deer body. Without the same name recognition, animals like the huemul or the saiga (a kind of antelope) or the takin (a member of the camel family) are less likely to receive the funding needed to study the challenges they face and the efforts that could mean the difference between rebound and extinction. Wildlife conservation biologist and CSU researcher Joel Berger advocates for these lesser-known species and one of the world’s preeminent field biologists, and focuses on species in North America, Mongolia, Namibia, and the Arctic.
fields.Spatial Angle: Included a map (.docx) but no spatial files. Recreate the map (so it's interactive).
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Species like the heumul, the rarest species of deer in the Americas, the saiga (a kind of antelope), and the takin (a member of the camel family) depend on name recognition to survive the effects of climate change.
fields.sp-Tagline: How naming can prevents extinction
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Species like the heumul, the rarest species of deer in the Americas, the saiga (a kind of antelope), and the takin (a member of the camel family) depend on name recognition to survive the effects of climate change.

fields.en-Tagline: Eating grains to improve gut health
fields.Research Blurb: The human gut contains tens of trillions of microorganisms, and these bacteria interact intimately with the immune system. The food that we eat impacts which bacteria are present and can ultimately reduce the risk of developing cancer and infectious disease. Dr. Elizabeth Ryan studies one of the world’s most abundant foods — rice — and its potential role in both modulating gut health to reduce disease, and increasing food security in lower- and middle-income countries. Ryan works in many countries but is starting a new project with the International Rice Research Institute in the Philippines, characterizing the way rice byproducts like rice bran can be used to improve global health and food security.
fields.Spatial Angle: Map of major rice crops in the US
fields.sp-Tagline: Eating grains to improve gut health

fields.en-Tagline: Science as a catalyst for social change
fields.Research Blurb: CSU Professor Robin Reid works with people in Kenya, Mongolia, and Colorado, applying science to help them address issues that matter most to their communities. A professor in the Department of Ecosystem Science and Sustainability, Reid heads CSU's Center for Collaborative Conservation. She spent 20 years in East Africa, where she developed a process of continuous engagement among landowners, communities, nongovernmental organizations, government, and scientists to address issues ranging from elephant poaching in Africa to wildfire mitigation in the American West.
fields.Spatial Angle: Wildfire prevalence in the US. Areas where elephant poaching is the most severe.
fields.sp-Tagline: Science as a catalyst for social change
fields.sp-StoryTitle: Transformación a través de la colaboración

fields.en-Tagline: Promoting diversity and inclusion in athletics
fields.Research Blurb: Dr. Albert Bimper, Jr., senior associate athletic director for diversity and inclusion and associate professor of ethnic studies at CSU, understands that student-athletes in college often don't see much further than the boundaries of their playing field. Balancing the demands of school and competition keeps many athletes from experiencing some of the best parts of college life — including the chance to study abroad. Bimper, a 2006 CSU graduate who went on to play on the Indianapolis Colts Super Bowl champion team, returned to his alma mater with a goal of promoting diversity and inclusion in Athletics and improving the overall academic experience of student working their way through college as athletes. Bimper created the Green and Global service experience, which takes a group of student-athletes each summer to Petersfield, Jamaica, to stretch their boundaries, immerse themselves in another culture, and learn to better understand their role and connections as global citizens.
fields.Spatial Angle: Jamaica Country Boundary and Larimer County Boundary with line connecting the two
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Student-athletes work hard and may not have many opportunities to experience college life outside of their sport.
fields.sp-Tagline: Promoting diversity and inclusion in athletics
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Student-athletes work hard and may not have many opportunities to experience college life outside of their sport.

fields.Research Focus: Climate Change, Food Security, Human-Elephant Conflict - Uganda
fields.en-Tagline: How do you respond to a changing environment?
fields.Research Blurb: Jonathan Salerno, new to CSU, is an ecologist in the Department of Human Dimensions of Natural Resources studying how and why humans make decisions, particularly in response to environmental changes. Salerno’s work tries to better understand human behavior in the context of biodiversity conservation and natural resource management. One of his current research projects focuses on human-elephant interactions, mostly through crop depredation, in southern Africa, and people adapt to negative impacts to support food security.
fields.Spatial Angle:
How the heck can we map human-elephant interactions and food security?? Let's do it. 

Contact about sharing .shp of boundary that was mentioned in email response to Lauren (see sharepoint)

Tungamalenga, Iringa Region, Tanzania (-7.834614, 35.096288).
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Farmers, livestock keepers, and rural resource users around the world will increasingly need to adapt to changes in climate.
fields.sp-Tagline: How do you respond to a changing environment?
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Farmers, livestock keepers, and rural resource users around the world will increasingly need to adapt to changes in climate.

fields.en-Tagline: The bond between science and societies
fields.Research Blurb: The Geospatial Centroid in the Morgan Library at CSU, directed by professor Melinda Laituri, serves a dual role. CSU faculty and students can use a multitude of GIS programs through the Centroid to map and analyze data across disciplines and for a variety of purposes — vegetation cover, population growth, animal migration. But Dr. Laituri also wants the Centroid to be an educational tool, promoting critical thinking around how to use tools like GIS properly, and both what can and cannot be learned from technology.
fields.Spatial Angle: Let's work with Laituri on this and perhaps showcase one of the Secondary Cities Interactive maps that she has developed.
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: By 2030, almost 60% of the world’s population will live in urban areas...and 95% of urban expansion in the next decades will take place in the developing world.
fields.sp-Tagline: The bond between science and societies
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: By 2030, almost 60% of the world’s population will live in urban areas...and 95% of urban expansion in the next decades will take place in the developing world.

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.en-Tagline: Integrated water resource management in a changing world
fields.Research Blurb: In today’s data-driven world, global challenges cannot be solved without access to relevant, accurate information — fast. Under the direction of professor and founder Mazdak Arabi, CSU’s One Water Solutions Institute (OWSI) has developed a robust portfolio of cloud-based software and research tools to equip public, private, and nongovernmental entities with world-class research and innovations necessary to address existing and emerging challenges in watershed sustainability and management. OWSI’s eRAMS (Environmental Resource Assessment and Management System) platform, created by Arabi, delivers location-based information, data analytics and modeling, and content management tools to inform the plans, policies, and practices of water-focused stakeholders and decisionmakers around the world.
fields.Spatial Angle: map of projects worldwide
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Water is the world’s most vital resource and a critical sustainability issue in the 21st century.
fields.sp-Tagline: Integrated water resource management in a changing world
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Water is the world’s most vital resource and a critical sustainability issue in the 21st century.
fields.sp-StoryTitle: Modelado de la calidad del agua

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.en-Tagline: Resilient water resources infrastructure
fields.Research Blurb: The world runs on water — and Neil Grigg, a civil and environmental engineering professor at CSU, studies how to protect water systems from natural disasters and terrorist attacks. This focus is just the latest aspect of Grigg's critical research; he's been helping to educate and work alongside the world's top water administrators since the 1960s. His research on engineering and management systems for water resources has influenced policy and infrastructure in Colombia, Egypt, Brazil, Somalia, and worldwide.
fields.Spatial Angle: Major waterways in Brazil
fields.sp-Tagline: Resilient water resources infrastructure

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.en-Tagline: Conserving greywater and stormwater for reuse
fields.Research Blurb: Without water, there is no life — and every drop counts. Sybil Sharvelle, Ph.D., associate professor of civil and environmental engineering at CSU, is researching water conservation systems such as graywater and stormwater reuse in urban and arid environments. In 2018, Sharvelle and her team secured a $3 million NSF grant to develop a national traineeship program to train the next generation of scientific leaders “to tackle complex societal programs.” The program — InTERFEWS (Interdisciplinary Training, Education and Research in Food-Energy-Water Systems in Semi-Arid Regions) — taps the skills and interests of Ph.D. students from disparate disciplines to research innovations that foster a more sustainable, waste-free future for all.
fields.sp-Tagline: Conserving greywater and stormwater for reuse

fields.Research Focus: Bat viruses & infectious disease ecology in Uganda
fields.en-Tagline: Understanding the spread of pathogens by studying bats
fields.Research Blurb: Bats, the only mammals with powered flight, are the second-most abundant order of mammals behind rodents and carry an equally impressive assemblage of viruses, many of which can make people sick. In Uganda, Dr. Rebekah Kading's lab studies not only which viruses the bats are infected with, but also how those viruses may be transmitted. By better understanding how these pathogens spread, we can paint a picture of the possible ways humans may be exposed, and how to prevent the next virus outbreak.
fields.Spatial Angle: map of Zika forest; how do we make this interactive by looking at pathogen spread?
fields.sp-Tagline: Understanding the spread of pathogens by studying bats

fields.en-Tagline: Dismantling the supply chains of wildlife trafficking
fields.Research Blurb: Supply chain management is usually used to build up a business, but CSU professor John McDonald wants to use supply chain management to bring down wildlife-destroying criminals. McDonald’s work in Africa is centered in Sri Lanka. Illegal wildlife trafficking generates an estimated $23 billion each year in the worldwide criminal economy. Thriving illegal businesses, just like legal ones, have a steady — and often complicated — integrated flow of purchasing and distribution operations. Disrupting the supply chain can kill the business. Understanding the supply chain of wildlife trafficking may be able to help slow the crime and prosecute criminals.
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Illegal wildlife trafficking generates an estimated $23 billion each year in the worldwide criminal economy.
fields.sp-Tagline: Dismantling the supply chains of wildlife trafficking
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Illegal wildlife trafficking generates an estimated $23 billion each year in the worldwide criminal economy.

fields.en-Tagline: Working to understand the pathogenesis of West Nile virus
fields.Spatial Angle: Covid Spread map
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: Livestock and agriculture are the primary economic activities in Kimtang, a village of 80 households in the hilly Nuwakot District of Nepal.
fields.sp-Tagline: Working to understand the pathogenesis of West Nile virus
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: Livestock and agriculture are the primary economic activities in Kimtang, a village of 80 households in the hilly Nuwakot District of Nepal.

fields.en-Tagline: Reducing viruses in domestic cats
fields.Research Blurb: All cats — domestic and wild — can become infected with feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV), resulting in a disease process comparable to HIV in humans. CSU veterinarian Dr. Sue VandeWoude’s laboratory studies factors that contribute to FIV transmission and the development and progression of the disease in cats. The ultimate goal of this research is to translate these findings to better understand viruses in humans. Dr. VandeWoude is currently on a Fulbright sabbatical studying wildlife disease ecology in Tasmania.
fields.en-PopUpCardContent: All cats — domestic and wild — can become infected with feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV), resulting in a disease process comparable to HIV in humans.
fields.sp-Tagline: Reducing viruses in domestic cats
fields.sp-PopUpCardContent: All cats — domestic and wild — can become infected with feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV), resulting in a disease process comparable to HIV in humans.

fields.en-Tagline: Balancing agricultural and nutritional diversity
fields.Research Blurb: In developing countries like Ecuador, as populations shift from rural to urban areas, diets often shift from traditional, grain- and vegetable-based fare to a more Western diet, high in sugar and fat. Professor Chris Melby with the Colorado School of Public Health at CSU studies how nutrition — and lack of access to diverse, healthy, nutritious foods — contributes to the chances of having a life-changing illness like stroke, heart disease, or diabetes. Melby is working with colleagues and graduate students in Ecuador to study how to help communities navigate this "nutrition transition," maximizing dietary diversity and minimizing risks for malnutrition and obesity.
fields.Spatial Angle: human migration; increase in health outcomes; rural diets and urban diets
fields.sp-Tagline: Balancing agricultural and nutritional diversity

fields.en-Tagline: Unearthing microscopic fertility in Antarctica
fields.Research Blurb: In Antarctica, the frozen ground looks barren – but dig into it, and put it under a microscope, and you’ll see tiny rugged worms, nematodes, that could help unlock our understanding of Earth’s changing climate. CSU professor Diana Wall has been making the voyage to the bottom of the globe every year since 1989 — more than 30 years of studying the life hidden in the Antarctic soil. Exploring the soil, studying the diversity of microbes and invertebrates, can shed light on how human activities around the world affect the health, productivity, and fertility of soils worldwide.
fields.sp-Tagline: Unearthing microscopic fertility in Antarctica
